The is the last bug blocking side-by-side remoting on Nano Server. The root cause of this issue was that M.P.ALC.dll was getting included in the TPA list twice. Once for the side by side PSHOME and once for the inbox location. This caused CoreCLR to load the inbox version of the assembly when it should load the side-by-side version instead.

Fixes the bug where PowerShell failed to start locally when run for the first time as a regular user.

Here is the fixed behavior:

``` powershell
PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0.7> set-executionpolicy -Scope localmachine bypass
set-executionpolicy : Access to the path 'c:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0.7\PowerShellProperties.json' is denied.
To change the execution policy for the default (LocalMachine) scope, start Windows PowerShell with the "Run as
administrator" option. To change the execution policy for the current user, run "Set-ExecutionPolicy -Scope
CurrentUser".
At line:1 char:1
+ set-executionpolicy -Scope localmachine bypass
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : PermissionDenied: (:) [Set-ExecutionPolicy], UnauthorizedAccessException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : System.UnauthorizedAccessException,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetExecutionPolicyCo
   mmand
PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0.7> set-executionpolicy -Scope CurrentUser bypass
PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0.7> get-executionpolicy -list

        Scope ExecutionPolicy
        ----- ---------------
MachinePolicy       Undefined
   UserPolicy       Undefined
      Process       Undefined
  CurrentUser          Bypass
 LocalMachine       Undefined
```

Compared to inbox PowerShell's behavior in the same scenario:

``` powershell
PS C:\Users\mirichmo> set-executionpolicy -Scope LocalMachine Unrestricted

Execution Policy Change
The execution policy helps protect you from scripts that you do not trust. Changing the execution policy might expose you to the security risks described in
the about_Execution_Policies help topic at http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=135170. Do you want to change the execution policy?
[Y] Yes  [A] Yes to All  [N] No  [L] No to All  [S] Suspend  [?] Help (default is "N"): y
set-executionpolicy : Access to the registry key 'HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\PowerShell\1\ShellIds\Microsoft.PowerShell' is denied. To change the
execution policy for the default (LocalMachine) scope, start Windows PowerShell with the "Run as administrator" option. To change the execution policy for the
current user, run "Set-ExecutionPolicy -Scope CurrentUser".
At line:1 char:1
+ set-executionpolicy -Scope LocalMachine Unrestricted
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : PermissionDenied: (:) [Set-ExecutionPolicy], UnauthorizedAccessException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : System.UnauthorizedAccessException,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.SetExecutionPolicyCommand
```

body:
Install-PowerShellRemoting.ps1 assumes that it is run from within the instance of PowerShell that it is registering. #1626 blocks this scenario.

To fix it for Aug17th, we need to add a new optional parameter to the script to enable inbox PowerShell to register the remoting endpoint for another instance of PowerShell.

-PowerShellHome <absolute path to the PSHOME of the new PowerShell instance>

The script should be able to extract the PowerShell version number from $PSHOME\powershell.version instead of from $psversiontable.psversion. Those two bits of information are all the script needs to register the PowerShell endpoint.

body:
Add a script named Install-PowerShellRemoting.ps1 to install pwrshplugin.dll and activate the WInRM endpoint for that version of PowerShell Core. The script must be run from within that instance of PowerShell and run with Administrator privileges. 
The script shall:
1. Copy pwrshplugin.dll to $env:windir\system32\powershell<version>
2. Create the remoting configuration file
3. Register the endpoint with WinRM.

This is a short-term fix for issue #1193. That issue still specifies the desired long-term experience.

I developed module [MarkdownLinkCheck](https://github.com/vors/MarkdownLinkCheck) fully on OS X. To my great surprise, I didn't encounter any cross-platform problems when I tested the result on inbox Windows PS version. 
It's particularly remarkable, because there is a binary part (netstandard assembly) in the package, but it works fine on full framework.

Today I tried to publish the module to PSGallery and it turns out to be **the only place** in the whole development cycle that required me to hop back to a windows machine.

Here is the result that I got on OS X:

```
PS /Users/vors/dev/MarkdownLinkCheck> Publish-Module -Name MarkdownLinkCheck -Verbose -RequiredVersion 0.1.0                                 
Publish-Module : Publish-Module is not supported on Nano Server and PowerShellCore.
```

body:
Is this comment really true?

``` csharp
// NetworkCredential constructor only accepts plain string password in CoreCLR
// Since user can already access the plain text password via PSCredential.GetNetworkCredential().Password,
// this change won't be a security issue for PS on CSS.
...
```

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/Credential.cs#L277

What I mean is that this is a non-trivial security regression compared to WindowsPowerShell, right?

Regardless of whether **the author** can access passwords ...

The "security issue" is a question of whether the password is stored in memory indefinitely (with non-deterministic garbage collection) as a string _that another user could read._

In the case of CoreFx NetworkCredential, the answer is yes.

With the full Framework and SecureString, as of 4.0 the answer is no.

Enable path globbing for native commands

E.g. `ls *.md` expands to `ls /path/to/README.md /path/to/CHANGELOG.md`

If expansion fails, the argument is sent literally, so `ls foo*` results in `/usr/bin/ls: cannot access foo*: No such file or directory`.

Don't glob expand if the verbatim marker was used.

/cc @lzybkr @JamesWTruher 

After tracing what the native command parameter binder does, it seems most reasonable to add this logic to `appendOneNativeArgument`. I know that doesn't sound right, but in fact it already deals with being sent an argument that gets expanded to a list. However I could be completely wrong, as the code around here is a bit strange.

When a `parameter.ParameterNameSpecified` is true, we don't want to glob, as this correlates to `-flag`. Moreover, the `CommandParameterInternal` should probably be updated to interpret `--flag` as a `Parameter` (instead of an `Argument`); as it does not currently.

We want to glob when `parameter.ArgumentSpecified` is true, and only once it's been converted to a string (or expanded to a set of strings) (which happens in the poorly named `appendOneNativeArgument` function).

We do not want to glob if the `--%` verbatim marker was seen.

I need to add tests, but figured I'd get this up for review.

Also I already have one known bug: globbing doesn't appear to work for `.dotfiles`. So although `*.md` works, `.gi*` and `*git*` does not work. But it doesn't have anything to do with these changes, it fails similarly for `Get-ChildItem` too. I'll file a bug report tomorrow.

body:
JsonConfigFileProcessor needs inter-process synchronization to handle competing IO from different processes on the same file. If a process attempts to read the file while another process has the write lock, the read will fail. Within a single process, this is gracefully managed by ReaderWriterLockSlim. We need an inter-process version of it for this scenario.
## Steps to reproduce
1. Start powershell and attach a debugger to it. 
2. Set a BP in SetExecutionPolicy
3. `Set-ExecutionPolicy -Scope LocalMachine Restricted`
4. Step through the code until it opens the FileStream for the config file
5. In another process, start PowerShell and `Get-ExecutionPolicy -list`
## Expected behavior

The second process should block until the first finishes its write.
## Actual behavior

``` powershell
PS > get-executionpolicy -list

        Scope ExecutionPolicy
        ----- ---------------
MachinePolicy       Undefined
   UserPolicy       Undefined
      Process       Undefined
get-executionpolicy : The process cannot access the file
'C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Local\PowerShell\Configuration\PowerShellProperties.json' because it is being used by another process.
At line:1 char:1
+ get-executionpolicy -list
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (:) [Get-ExecutionPolicy], IOException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : System.IO.IOException,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetExecutionPolicyCommand
```
## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

``` powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-alpha.7-116-gd26b614837f657c1984d0f5e89c9395e4c56e6b8
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
CLRVersion
PSEdition                      PowerShellCore
WSManStackVersion              3.0
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}

```

body:
When validating the .NET Core RTM drop in NanoServer, we found two issues that cause powershell.exe and pwrshplugin.dll crash:
1. Bug in AssemblyLoadContext causes Resolving event doesn't work [https://github.com/dotnet/coreclr/issues/5837](url)
2. Bug in JIT causes the call from native code to managed code to break when standard IO is redirected (pwrshplugin.dll is hosted by WinRM service, and WinRM service redirect the IO when creating host process). [https://github.com/dotnet/coreclr/issues/6460](url)

CoreCLR team has approved the work to drop NuGet packages for the 2 powershell fixes. So we need to adopt the new package for PowerShell as soon as they come out.
- [x] Adopt the new CoreCLR nuget packages that contains 2 powershell fixes
- [x] Make OSPS depend on Newtonsoft.Json 9.0
title: Adopt the new CoreCLR NuGet packages that contains the 2 powershell fixes
